// window.CenterLeft ( _parent_left; _parent_width ) // Purpose: Returns the left coordinate that the current window should have to center within a // parent window of the given dimentions. // Parameters: _parent_left: The left coordinate of the parent window. // _parent_width: The width of the parent window. // Version: 1.0 - Charles Ross - 15-04-09 // 1.1 - Charles Ross - 17-04-06 - Fixed bug that referenced incorrect dimension. // Todo: Provide examples. // Example: sample = result Max( ( ( _parent_width - Get( WindowWidth ) ) / 2 ) + _parent_left; 0 )

// window.CenterTop ( _parent_top; _parent_height ) // Purpose: Returns the top coordinate that the current window should have to center within a // parent window of the given dimentions. // Parameters: _parent_top: The top coordinate of the parent window. // _parent_height: The height of the parent window. // Author: Charles Ross // Version: 1.0 - Charles Ross - 15-04-09 // Todo: Provide examples. // Example: sample = result Max( ( ( _parent_height - Get( WindowHeight ) ) / 2 ) + _parent_top; 0 )

// window.Offscreen // Purpose: Returns a large negative number for hiding offscreen utility windows, overriding this for // developers. // Requirements: devp.IsDeveloper // Author: Charles Ross // Version: 1.0 - Charles Ross - 15-04-09 // 1.1 - Charles Ross - 17-04-11 - Added ability for dev to override on screen with shift key // 1.2 - Charles Ross - 17-08-13 - Added ability for dev to override on screen with global variable // Example: // Assuming the current user is not a developer... // window.Offscreen = -9000 Let ( [ _on_screen = dev.IsDeveloper and ( not modifier.KeyActive ( modifier.Shift ) ) and ( not $$_WINDOW_OFFSCREEN_FOR_DEVELOPER ) ] ; Case ( _on_screen ; 0 ; -9000 ) )

// window.Utility ( _id ) // Purpose: Returns a window name that can be referred to later, often with a Close Window step. // Parameters: _id: The identifier to refer to the window with when a script works with multiple utility // windows. // Version: 1.0.0 - Charles Ross - 15-04-09 // 1.0.1 - Charles Ross - 17-12-07 - Use UUID as default if no ID is given. // Example: window.Utility ( "entity" ) = "utility_window_entity" "utility_window" & "_" & dev.Default ( _id ; Get ( UUID ) )

// xmlp.ExtractData ( _xml ; _tag ; _idx ) // // Purpose: Returns the contents of the instanceth attribute of the xml. // // Parameters: _xml: The XML data to parse // _tag: The tag to get the data from // _idx: Which instance of the tag to get. // // Requirements: requirements // // Version: 1.0 written 08-04-29 by Andy Knasinski // // Notes: https://www.briandunning.com/cf/1 // // Todo: Debug edit in comments below that was made by Daniel A. Shockley which is supposed // to be able to handle tags with attributes (i.e., <InvNum attrb="value">123</InvNum>). // // Example: // Let ( // [ // _xml = List ( // "<xml>" ; // " <InvNum>123</InvNum>" ; // " <InvNum>456</InvNum>" ; // " <InvNum>789</InvNum>" ; // "</xml>" // ) // ] ; // // xmlp.ExtractData ( _xml ; "InvNum" ; 2 ) // ) = 456 // https://www.briandunning.com/cf/1 Let ( [ _xml_len = Length ( _xml ) ; _tag_len = Length ( _tag ) ; _idx = If ( IsEmpty ( _idx ) ; 1 ; _idx ) ; _open = "<" & _tag & ">" ; _close = "</" & _tag & ">" ; _open_pos = Position ( _xml ; _open ; 1 ; _idx ) ; _close_pos = Position ( _xml ; _close ; 1 ; _idx ) ; _start = _open_pos + _tag_len + 2 ; _len = _xml_len - ( _xml_len - _close_pos ) - ( _open_pos + _tag_len + 2 ) ] ; Case( IsEmpty ( _xml ) or IsEmpty ( _tag ) or ( PatternCount ( _xml ; _open ) = 0 ) ; dev.Nil ; Middle ( _xml ; _start ; _len ) ) ) /* //version 1.1, Daniel A. Shockley Let ( [ XML_Length = Length ( _xml ) ; Attribute_Length = Length ( _attribute ) ; Get_Instance = If ( IsEmpty ( _instance ) ; 1 ; _instance ) ; posOpenTagStart = Position ( _xml ; "<" & _attribute; 1; Get_Instance ) ; posNextOpen = Position ( _xml ; "<"; posOpenTagStart + 1; 1 ) ; posOpenTagFinish = Position ( _xml ; ">"; posOpenTagStart; 1 ) ; posCloseTagStart = Position( _xml; "</" & _attribute & ">"; posOpenTagFinish; 1 ) ]; Case( IsEmpty ( _xml ) or IsEmpty ( _attribute ) or ( posOpenTagStart = 0 ) // Attribute not in XML at all or ( posNextOpen>0 and posOpenTagFinish> posNextOpen ) // Attribute seems to start, but another tag starts before opening tag brackets close ; "" ; Middle ( _xml ; posOpenTagFinish + 1 ; posCloseTagStart - posOpenTagFinish - 1 ) ) )*/

// text.SubstituteFirstVariable ( _text ) // Purpose: Find the first delimited variable in the text and substitute in the value of the variable // Parameters: _text: The text to substitute the variable's value in // Version: 20-02-23 - Charles Ross // Notes: Variables should be delimited by double braces as in {{$_var_name}} // Example: sample = result Let ( [ _start = Position ( _text ; "{{" ; 1 ; 1 ) ; _end = Position ( _text ; "}}" ; _start ; 1 ) ; _var_name = Middle ( _text ; _start + 2 ; _end - _start - 2 ) ; _value = Evaluate ( _var_name ) ; _result = Substitute ( _text ; "{{" & _var_name & "}}" ; _value ) ; _ = "" ] ; _result )

// apperr.AuthorizationError // Purpose: Returns the error code for the named error // Version: 1.0 written 20-02-24 by Charles Ross // Notes: Meant to be compared with "~error" key in Get ( ScriptResult ) // Example: apperr.ConfigError = "Configuration error" "Authorization error"

PrivilegeSet.name: [Data Entry Only]
PrivilegeSet.Description: write access to all records, no design access

PrivilegeSet.name: [Read-Only Access]
PrivilegeSet.Description: read access to all records, no design access, write access to all global fields

PrivilegeSet.name: Executive
PrivilegeSet.Description: Can access all data, but no development privileges

PrivilegeSet.name: Accounting
PrivilegeSet.Description: Can access all user data as well as accounting data

PrivilegeSet.name: Managers
PrivilegeSet.Description: Can access all user data at or below their level in the corporate hierarchy

PrivilegeSet.name: Users
PrivilegeSet.Description: Can access their own data and data they create

PrivilegeSet.name: Guest
PrivilegeSet.Description: No access, used for accounts login to facilitate forgotten passwords

Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 2. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Purpose: Executes when the solution first opens. Version: 19-07-07 - Charles Ross

Purpose: Executes when the solution closes. Version: 19-07-07 - Charles Ross
Purpose: Executes when a window within the current file closes. Return: `True` if the event should proceed, `False` if it should be canceled. Version: 19-07-07 - Charles Ross
Purpose: Executes when a record loads on the layout the trigger is attached to. Parameters: Sender: Optional parameter that specifies the object initiating the event. Version: 19-07-07 - Charles Ross

dialog 2.0.0 ============ The `dialog` module includes two types of features. The first is just a single script that ddisplays a dialog in a loop until tests have been passed. Failed tests alter the dialog box informing the user of the requirements to pass the test. But FileMaker doesn't support more complex dialogs, such as a dialog box that includes menus or even a portal. Card windows are perfect for this, however, and the other set of scripts supports using layouts as dialog boxes for record creation and editing. The module includes features for validating the data in a creation or edit dialog and support for using the keyboard to cancel or confirm the dialog. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library - This file's `primary-key` module - This file's `window` module Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the this file. 2. Import the `primary-key` and `window` modules if they aren't already present in your solution. 3. Import the `dialog` script folder. 4. If you want to take advantage of the automated testing, create a layout with a context into `FUNIT` and set it up like the `test_dialog` layout in this file. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- For simple dialogs, call `dialog-loop: Begin Loop ( Title ; BaseMsg ; Inputs ; Tests ; Msgs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )`. See the comments in that script for the needs of the various parameters. For layout based dialogs, you have a few options. - To prepare the dialog window: - For the layout that will serve as a popin dialog, assign the `dialog: onRecordCommit ( IsValid )` script to the `OnRecordCommit` script trigger, passing a value for the `Validation` parameter that is `True` when the data is valid or an error message when validation fails. - Assign the `dialog: onObjectKeystroke Layout` script to the layout's `OnLayoutKeystroke` trigger (or ensure it's executed if you use a dispatch system for script triggers). - For any large text fields that should capture carriage returns, assign the `dialog: onObjectKeystroke Long Text Field` script to the field's `OnObjectKeystroke` trigger (or ensure it's executed if you use a dispatch system for script triggers). - Assign the `dialog: Save` script to execute with a button that should save changes and close the popin window. - Assign the `dialog: Cancel` script to execute with a button that should cancel changes to data in the popin window. - If you use the `window` module, popins windows will be centered horizontally within their parent window and offset from the top of their parent window by 50 pixels with a size resulting from an `Adjust Window [ Resize to Fit ]` script call. > Note: Since the dialog window creates a modal dialog that can only be closed via the `Close Window` script step, introducing the possibility of the window being stuck open during development, the `dialog: Cancel` script has an emergency exit. If a developer (logged in with "[Full Access]" privileges) clicks a button attached to this script while holding down the "Shift" key, the window will immediately close. - To activate the dialog window designed to edit a record, execute the `dialog: Edit ( Rule ; Layout ; ID {; PreCommit ; PostCommit ; PostClose } )`, passing the following parameters: - `Auth`: Send the string `True` if the user has permission to edit the record, or an error message that should be displayed to the user if they do not have permission. - `Layout`: The name of the layout that should be used for the popin window. - `ID`: The primary key of the record to present to the user for editing. - `Callbacks`: A let-notation dictionary of callbacks to perform, with the following potential keys: - `pre_commit`: A script name to execute before committing - `post_commit`: A script name to execute after committing - `post_close`: A script name to execute after closing the dialog - To activate the popin window and create a new record, execute the `popin: New ( Rule ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; PreCommit ; PostCommit ; PostClose } )` script, passing the following parameters: - `Rule`: Send the string `"OK"` if the user has permission to create the record, or an error message that should be displayed to the user if they do not have permission. - `Layout`: The name of the layout that should be used for the popin window. - `Fields`: The optional list of fields that should be assigned values to the new record. - `Values`: The optional list of values to assign to the fields listed in the `Fields` parameter. Note that these two lists must have equal value counts. - `Callbacks`: A let-notation dictionary of callbacks to perform, with the following potential keys: - `pre_commit`: A script name to execute before committing - `post_commit`: A script name to execute after committing - `post_close`: A script name to execute after closing the dialog Here is an example of using the script parameter custom functions to pass parameters to `popin: New ( Rule ; Layout {; Fields ; Values ; PreCommit ; PostCommit ; PostClose } )`: Let ( [ _auth = Case ( Get ( AccountPrivilegeSetName ) = "Management" ; True ; "You must be a manager to create invoice records." ) ; _layout = "Dialog New Invoice" ; _fields = List ( GetFieldName ( INV::date_created ) ; GetFieldName ( INV::time_created ) ) ; _values = List ( Get ( CurrentDate ) ; Get ( CurrentTime ) ) ; _pre_commit = "check_invoice_line_items" ; _post_commit = "show_invoice_preview" ; _post_close = "update_screen" ] ; script.Param ( "Auth" ; _auth ) & script.Param ( "Layout" ; _layout ) & script.Param ( "Fields" ; _fields ) & script.Param ( "Values" ; _values ) & script.Param ( "PreCommit" ; _pre_save ) & script.Param ( "PostCommit" ; _post_save ) & script.Param ( "PostClose" ; _post_cose ) ) To Do ----- Try to find a way to full automate testing this module. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-07-30 1.0.1 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-05-01 - Minor edits to `popin priv: New...` 1.0.2 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-05-25 - Fix variable typos. 1.1.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-25 - Refactor to conform to current conventions, take advantage of `Perform Script by Name` 2.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-09-21 - Combined popin and dialog modules [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return the name of a popin window's title given the layout and primary key value. Parameters: Layout: The name of the layout from which to calculate the window name. ID: Optional: The primary key of the record being edited on edit popins. Return: A let-notation dictionary with a key of `~window_name` that should be the window's title. Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 20-01-12 - Charles Ross - Update to work with current conventions and funit testing
DO NOT EDIT ABOVE THIS LINE

Calculation.Text: Let ( [ _title = Case ( dev.IsSet ( $ID ) ; "Edit " ; "New " ) & Trim ( Substitute ( $Layout ; "popin" ; dev.Nil ) ) & Case ( dev.IsSet ( $ID ) ; " (" & $ID & ")" ; dev.Nil ) ] ; _title )

ScriptReference.name: dialog: Begin Loop ( Title ; BaseMsg ; Inputs ; Tests ; Msgs {; Btns ; Labels ; PWStart} )

Comment.value: Purpose: Provide a looping custom message dialog box that returns up to three input fields after conditions have been met or the user has canceled. Parameters: Title: The dialog box title. BaseMsg: The beginning message for the dialog box which is append after any conditions fail. Inputs: The number of input fields, an integer from 0 to 3. Tests: A let-notation array of tests that should be passed. Each test should be `Evaluate`able. Msgs: A let-notation array of matching messages when conditions fail. Msgs and Tests must match in count. Btns: Optional: A let-notation array of button names, defaults to "OK" and "Cancel". If provided, must include at least two buttons. Labels: Optional: A let-notation array of labels. If not provided, no labels are given. PWStart: Optional: The first input field to make a password field. All inputs after the first password field will also be password fields. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: ~canceled: `True` if the user canceled the dialog box ~input[1]: The contents of the first input field ~input[2]: The contents of the second input field ~input[3]: The contents of the third input field Version: 18-07-26 - Charles Ross Notes: If the Btns parameter is provided, the last button will be the cancel button.

Callbacks: Optional: A let-notation dictionary with the following possible keys: pre_commit: A script name to execute before committing post_commit: A script name to execute after committing post_close: A script name to execute after closing Version: 17-12-01 - Charles Ross 19-08-25 - Charles Ross - Conform to funit conventions in error reporting Notes: The `Fields` and `Values` parameters should be constructed using `let.Array`. Any name can be used, but it must be consistent for each parameter, i.e.: let.Array ( "Fields" ; 1 ; GetFieldName ( MOD::text_field ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 1 ; "first value" ) & let.Array ( "Fields" ; 2 ; GetFieldName ( MOD::date_field ) ) & let.Array ( "Values" ; 2 ; "second value" )

Comment.value: Purpose: Provide a looping custom message dialog box that returns up to three input fields after conditions have been met or the user has canceled. Parameters: Title: The dialog box title. BaseMsg: The beginning message for the dialog box which is append after any conditions fail. Inputs: The number of input fields, an integer from 0 to 3. Tests: A let-notation array of tests that should be passed. Each test should be `Evaluate`able. Msgs: A let-notation array of matching messages when conditions fail. Msgs and Tests must match in count. Btns: Optional: A let-notation array of button names, defaults to "OK" and "Cancel". If provided, must include at least two buttons. Labels: Optional: A let-notation array of labels. If not provided, no labels are given. PWStart: Optional: The first input field to make a password field. All inputs after the first password field will also be password fields. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: ~button: The number corresponding to the button clicked ~canceled: `True` if the user canceled the dialog box ~input[1]: The contents of the first input field ~input[2]: The contents of the second input field ~input[3]: The contents of the third input field Version: 18-07-26 - Charles Ross Notes: If the Btns parameter is provided, the last button will be the cancel button. Todo: Shorten script by using subscripts, but get testing scripts in place first to make sure nothing breaks.

Calculation.Text: ( not script.AssignParams ) or ( $Inputs < 0 ) or ( $Inputs > 3 ) or ( not math.IsInteger ( $Inputs ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $Btns[1] ) and IsEmpty ( $Btns[2] ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $PWStart ) and ( not math.IsInteger ( $PWStart ) ) ) or ( dev.IsSet ( $PWStart ) and ( $PWStart > $Inputs ) )

Comment.value: Purpose: Show the appropriate dialog given the parameters Parameters: Title: The dialog box title. Msg: The message to show in the dialog. Inputs: The number of input fields, an integer from 0 to 3. Btns: Optional: A let-notation array of button names, defaults to "OK" and "Cancel". If provided, must include at least two buttons. Labels: Optional: A let-notation array of labels. If not provided, no labels are given. PWStart: Optional: The first input field to make a password field. All inputs after the first password field will also be password fields. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: ~button: The number corresponding to the button clicked ~canceled: `True` if the user canceled, `False` otherwise ~input_1`: The contents of the first first input field ~input_2`: The contents of the second first input field ~input_3`: The contents of the third first input field Version: 19-12-12 - Charles Ross

files 1.2.0 =========== The `files` module makes use of FileMaker 18+ data file script steps to perform common file actions. Requirements ------------ - This file's custom function library - The `funnit` module if you're going to run the test scripts Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the this file. 2. Import the `files` module folder. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- ### `files: Create Temporary Text File ( Name ; Contents ) Call this script with a filename for `Name` and the text contents for `Contents` to create a temporary file with that name and contentes. The return value is a let-notation dictionary with a single key, either `~path` if the operation was successful or `~error` if there was a problem. ### `files: Export Container to Temp ( Field ; Criteria )`: Given a fully-qualified field name and let-notation specified criteria, exports the container field's contents to the temporary folder. `Field` should be a fully-qualified field name returned by `GetFieldName` and `Criteria` should be a single let- notation dictionary with a key being the field name and the value the search term. ### `files: Read File Contents ( Path )`: Return the contents of the file at the give path. `Path` can be in either POSIX or FileMaker format. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-15 1.1.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-16 - Move `Export Container to Temp` from `utilities` to `files` module 1.2.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 20-01-10 - Add `files: Read File Contents ( Path )` script [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

funit 1.1.1 =========== The `funit` module provide a testing framework for FileMaker scripts. By naming test scripts with a certain pattern (and avoiding naming non-test scripts with that pattern) and conforming to some conventions for return values, this module will execute the test scripts and track which pass. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from this file. 2. Copy and paste the `FUNITCF` table from this file. 3. Import the `funit` folder of scripts. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- Call `funit: Run Scripts` to run all of the test scripts in this file and report on their success or failure. A test script is any script that has the string ": Test" or "Test: " in it. Note that the space after the colon in the second pattern is required. So, `module-name: Test This feature` and `Test: Another Testing Script` are both test scripts by this definition, but "Test My Feature" and "Performing Some Tests" are not. Within your test scripts, the return value of the script determines success or failure. A successful execution should exit with the following step: Exit Script [ Text Result: let.Set ( "~success" ; True ) ] If there is a failure, then the `~success` key should return `False` and another key should be included, `~error`, which contains information about why the test failed. For example: Exit Script [ Text Result: let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "Invalid configuration" ) ] After all the test scripts have executed, success or failure of any tests will be reported in a dialog box. If there are failures, the dialog box will also show each tests script name and `~error` key value. These values are also retained in a `$$_FUNIT_FAILED_TESTS` global variable so you can view them in the data viewer after the script exits. You also have the ability to run setup and teardown scripts. Any scripts with the string ": Setup" or "Setup: " will be executed before any tests, and any with the string ": Teardown" or "Teardown: " will be run after all tests have been completed. You can find an examle of this in the `audit-log` module. One more convention allows you to write scripts to be tested to determine if they're running within a test. Before test scripts are executed, a `$$_FUNIT_TESTING` global variable is sset to `True`. This allows a script to perhaps exit instead of halting during certain errors, or avoid a dialog box reporting an error to the user. Here's an example of the usse of the variable: If [ not script.AssignParams ] If [ not $$_FUNIT_TESTING ] Show Custom Dialog [ "Invalid Parameters" ; "Invalid parameters were sent to " & ... End If Exit Script [ Text Result: let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; ... End If The `$$_FUNIT_TESTING` variable is cleared out after all test scripts have been executed. Examples of all of these conventions can be found in the `slack-bot` module. Custom functions are tested with records in the `FUNITCF` table. Create a record there for each custom function you want to test, place the name of the custom function in the `function` field, a boolean-returning calculation in the `calc` field and make sure the `active` field is `1`. Each active function record will then be tested during the test suite. The `container` field can be used to store a file for functions that deal with containers. See the `container.Encode` custom function test for an example of this. Execute the test suite by running `funit: Run Tests` script. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-12 1.1.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-09-19 - Added setup and teardown support 1.1.1 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 20-01-06 - Expand documentation to include testing custom functions [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com
Purpose: Run all of the script and custom function tests Version: 19-09-11 - Charles Ross
Purpose: Run all of the script and custom function tests Version: 19-09-11 - Charles Ross 19-09-18 - Charles Ross - Add support for a testing transaction ID that can be used during log testing

Since the test module isn't itself tested, errors result in the script halting execution. Version: 19-09-19 - Charles Ross 20-01-06 - Charles Ross - Add test that parameter is one of the accepted values

Calculation.Text: "The script " & Quote ( Get ( ScriptName ) ) & " received in anvalid `Which` parameter: " & Get ( ScriptParameter )

UniqueValues ( List ( list.KeepItems ( ScriptNames ( dev.Nil ) ; "PatternCount ( %t ; \": \" & $Which )" ; "Text" ) ; list.KeepItems ( ScriptNames ( dev.Nil ) ; "PatternCount ( %t ; $Which & \": \" )" ; "Text" ) ) )

Comment.value: Purpose: Run all of the test scripts and return the number of tests and failures Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with two additional keys: `~script_count`: The number of scripts that were run `~script_fail_count`: The number of script tests that failed Version: 19-08-12 - Charles Ross 19-09-11 - Charles Ross - Abstract out the testing from the reporting Notes: Test scripts should return a let-notation dictionary with two possible keys: - ~success: Requied: `True` or `False` - ~error: Optional: If returned, should describe the error for the report presented to the user

Calculation.Text: UniqueValues ( List ( list.KeepItems ( ScriptNames ( dev.Nil ) ; "PatternCount ( %t ; \": Test\" )" ; "Text" ) ; list.KeepItems ( ScriptNames ( dev.Nil ) ; "PatternCount ( %t ; \"Test: \" )" ; "Text" ) ) )

Comment.value: Purpose: Run all of the custom function tests and the number of tests and failures Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with two additional keys: `~cf_count`: The number of custom functions that were tested `~cf_fail_count`: The number of custom function tests that failed Version: 19-09-11 - Charles Ross Notes: Custom function tests are stored in the `FUNITCF` table.

Calculation.Text: Let ( [ _sql = List ( "SELECT _function_field, _calc_field" ; "FROM _funitcf_table" ; "WHERE _test_field = ?" ; "AND _is_active_field = ?" ) ; _function_field = sql.QuotedFieldName ( FUNITCF::function ) ; _calc_field = sql.QuotedFieldName ( FUNITCF::calc ) ; _funitcf_table = sql.QuotedTableName ( FUNITCF::id ) ; _test_field = sql.QuotedFieldName ( FUNITCF::test ) ; _is_active_field = sql.QuotedFieldName ( FUNITCF::is_active ) ; _sql = Substitute ( _sql ; [ "_function_field" ; _function_field ] ; [ "_calc_field" ; _calc_field ] ; [ "_funitcf_table" ; _funitcf_table ] ; [ "_test_field" ; _test_field ] ; [ "_is_active_field" ; _is_active_field ] ) ; _result = ExecuteSQL ( _sql ; $_sep ; dev.Nil ; False ; True ) ] ; _result )

Comment.value: primary-key 1.0.0 ================= The `primary-key` module provides a single place to let other modules know how to identify a table's primary key. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 2. Import the `primary-key` folder of scripts. 3. Edit the `primary-key: Config` script so that it the $_pk variable stores the name of the field used as a primary key. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- Modules can call the `primary-key: Primary Key Name` script. It will return a let-notation dictionary with a key of "~pk_name", which will have the primary key name for its value. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 17-11-08 [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Comment.value: slack-bot 1.0.0 =============== The slack-bot module makes it easy to use the token from a Slack bot you've created and send messagees and files to a Slack account on which the bot has been installed and given sufficient scopes. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library - A Slack bot with chat:write:bot permission - The `funnit` module if you're going to run the test scripts Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Create your Slack bot at https://api.slack.com and give it the chat:write:bot permission. 2. Take note of the Bot User OAuth Access Token. 3. Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 4. Import the `slack-bot` folder of scripts into your solution. 5. Edit the `slack-bot: Settings` script to set the `$_token` variable to your Slack token. 6. If you want to take advantage of `funit` support, edit the `slack-bot: Settings` script to set the `$_test_user_id` to a valid Slack user ID that test messages can be sent to. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- First you need to get the Slack user IDs of the users you want to send a message to. The easiest way I've found so far to do this is to use Slack's `user.list` API tester at https://api.slack.com/methods/users.list/test. Enter your Bot User OAuth Access Token and click "Test Method". You'll get a JSON response with all the data about your users. (A future version of this will add routines for getting User IDs from `user.list`, but for now it needs to be done manually.) You will probably want to create a `slack_id` field in your users table to store this information. To send a message, call the `slack-bot: Send Message ( User ; Message )` script, passing the Slack user ID of the recipient to the `User` parameter and the text of the message to send in the `Message` parameter. To send a file, call the `slack-bot: Send File ( User ; Path {; Message} )` script, passing it the Slack user ID of the recipient to the `User` parameter and the FileMaker version of the path to the file you want to send. (Note that the custom function library has `path.TemporaryPath`, `path.DesktopPath`, and `path.DocumentsPath`, which will make constructing these paths easier, but the use of those function is not required.) You can also pass an options `Message` parameter to include a message with the file. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-10 [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return a let-notation structure of the settings needed for the module. Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: - "~token": The Bot User OAuth Token to authenticate using the Slack API - "~test_user_id": Optional: For integration with the `funit` module, used to send test messages Version: 19-08-10 - Charles Ross 19-09-13 - Charles Ross - Add support for `priv-set` module Notes: This module supports the `priv-set` module for storing the Slack token in a separate file. Within the `priv-set` JSON, the token should be stored within this module's settings using a "token" key.

Comment.value: When passing a file to `Insert from URL` with a variable name, the uploaded file will have a filename that's the variable's name. So, to have it have some approximation of the original file's name, we dynamically create a variable with the same name as the file, first removing characters from the filename that would be problematic during upload. `dev.SetVarByName` yet work for this because it quotes the value, which turns the file contents into the filename.

Calculation.Text: "$" & Substitute ( GetAsText ( $_file ) ; [" " ; "_" ] ; ["(" ; dev.Nil ] ; [")" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["+" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["-" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["=" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["≠" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["&" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["<" ; dev.Nil ] ; [">" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["," ; dev.Nil ] ; [";" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["[" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["]" ; dev.Nil ] ; [":" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["\"" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["$" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["/" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["*" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["^" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["}" ; dev.Nil ] ; ["{" ; dev.Nil ] )

List ( "--form file=@" & $_filename_var ; Case ( dev.IsSet ( $Message ) ; "--form " & Quote ( "initial_comment=" & $Message ) ; dev.Nil ) ; "--form channels=" & $User ; "--header " & Quote ( "Authorization: Bearer " & $~token ) )

Comment.value: window 1.0.0 ============ The window module provides a scripts to create generic windows for both the users and developers. Requirements ------------ - This file's custom function library Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 2. Import the `window` script folder and all of its sub-folders and scripts into your solution. See the comments within the `Script Parameter Passing Readme` for instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- When a new window is needed, call the `window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )` script. See the header comments for this script for details about the available parameters. If you need a window for context control, and therefore want it created offscreen for end-users but onscreen for developers, call the `window: New Utility ( Layout {; WindowID } )` script. This script will return the name of the window so that the calling script can close it. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 17-11-08 [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

ScriptReference.name: window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. Title: The title to give to the window. Style: Optional: Either "dialog" or "document", defaults to "dialog" Coords: Optional: The top and left coordinates where the window should be placed. If omitted, the window is centered within the parent window and offset 50 pixels from the parent window's top. Size: Optional: The height and width coordinates the windows should be sized to. If omitted, the width will be determined by `Adjust Window [ Resize to Fit ]` and the height by the minimum of that value and the parent window minus 100 pixels. Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross Notes: Coords and Size parameters should be specified using let-notation dictionaries. The keys for Coords should be `_top` and `_left` while those for Size should be `_height` and `_width`: let.Set ( "_top" ; 150 ) & let.Set ( "_left" ; 150 ) let.Set ( "_height" ; 600 ) & let.Set ( "_width" ; 600 )

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. WindowID: Optional: A unique ID for the window so it can be reliably closed later. Defaults to a UUID. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with additional key: ~window_name: The title of the window so the calling script can reference it if necessary Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New Utility ( Layout {; WindowID } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Confirm that new windows are properly created Return: A let-notation dictionary with the following keys: - ~success: `True` or `False` - ~error: Error text if an error occurred Version: 19-08-16 - Charles Ross

ScriptReference.name: window: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Calculation.Text: script.Param ( "Layout" ; $_layout ) & script.Param ( "Title" ; $_title ) & script.Param ( "Coords" ; let.Set ( "_left" ; $_left ) & let.Set ( "_top" ; $_top ) ) & script.Param ( "Size" ; let.Set ( "_width" ; $_width ) & let.Set ( "_height" ; $_height ) )

ScriptReference.name: window priv: New ( Layout ; Title {; Style ; Coords ; Size } )

Comment.value: Purpose: Creates a new window with the given parameters. Parameters: Layout: The layout to use for the popin window. Title: The title to give to the window. Style: Optional: One of "dialog", "document", "utility", "card", or "dimcard", defaults to "document". Coords: Optional: The top and left coordinates where the window should be placed. If omitted, the window is centered within the parent window and offset 50 pixels from the parent window's top. Size: Optional: The height and width coordinates the windows should be sized to. If omitted, the width will be determined by `Adjust Window [ Resize to Fit ]` and the height by the minimum of that value and the parent window minus 100 pixels. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary Version: 17-11-08 - Charles Ross 19-09-13 - Charles Ross - Allow close boxes in document and utility windows Notes: Coords and Size parameters should be specified using let-notation dictionaries. The keys for Coords should be "_top" and "_left" while those for Size should be "_height" and "_width". Windows are only created offscreen for users. When developers execute this script, windows are positioned at (0, 0). 1. Use $Coords if provided 2. Lacking $Coords, default to parent + 50 3. If vertical size fits within parent, done. 4. If vertical size does not fit within parent, extend bottom. 5. If vertical size still does not fit, extend top.

Calculation.Text: Case ( dev.IsSet ( $Coords ) ; let.Get ( $Coords ; "_top" ) ; Let ( [ _default = $_parent_top + 50 ; _top = Case ( _default + $_height > Get ( ScreenHeight ) ; Get ( ScreenHeight ) - $_height ; _default ) ] ; _top ) )

Comment.value: utilities 1.1.0 =============== The `utilities` module is for general utilities that are useful but not related, and therefore don't easily fit into other module umbrellas. Requirements ------------ - chiv-lib's custom function library Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the chiv-lib file. 2. Import the `utilities` module folder. See the comments within the `Script Parameter Passing Readme` for instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- The `utilities` module includes the following scripts: - `utilities: Go to Field by Name ( Field {; NewWindow} )`: Given a fully-qualified field name, exits in a state where the named field is the active field. - `utilities: Go to Record ( Table ; Criteria {; NewWindow } )`: Given a table name and let-notation specified criteria, exits in a state where that record is the current record. - `utilities: Clear All Global Fields`: Useful in the `OnFirstWindowOpen` script to remove any data from global fields, possibly left over from when the file was locally opened. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 17-11-08 1.0.1 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-07-30 - Removed `utilities: Clear Dialog Field Reps` as unecessary with FM17. 1.1.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-16 - Removed `Script Start` and `Toggle Field Value` as never used, move `Export Container to Temp` to `files` module [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return the settings required for this module. Return: A let-notation dictionary of settings with the following keys: ~global_exception_list: A list of fully-qualified fields that should not be cleared by `utilities: Clear All Global Fields` ~cascade_clears: A list of fully-qualified fields that when changed by `utilities: Toggle Field Value ( FieldName ; Value )` should have other fields cleared of values. Version: 17-11-30 - Charles Ross Notes: Since fully-qualified fields do not make valid keys with `let.Set`, use faux lists for the cascades: something like: List ( GetFieldName ( TABLE::field1 ) & "\¶" & GetFieldName ( TABLE::field2 ) ; GetFieldName ( TABLE::field3 ) & "\¶" & GetFieldName ( TABLE::field4 ) ) The above means that when `field1`'s value changes, `field2` should be cleared, and likewise for `field3` and `field4`.
DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE

Assumes that the table name has a layout with the same name. Currently only supports one criterion. Todo: Support multiple criteria.

accounts 1.1.0 ============ Allows centralized account management so that accounts can be creeeated, deleted, and have passwords changed across multiple files without access to the accounts system within FileMaker. Will also override the default login process so that a forgotten password can be sent to the user via Slack. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library - This file's `dialog` module - This file's `slack` module - This file's `priv-set` module - This file's `funit` module - This file's `primary-key` module - A table to link store account records Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from the this file. 2. Import the required modules listed above if they aren't already present in your solution. 3. Edit `accounts: Config` to set the values of `$_account_name_field` and `$_slack_id_field` to the approiate fully-qualified field names, i.e., `GetFieldName ( USR::account_name )`. 4. In the same script, set the value of `$_full_access_account` to the name of a full access account that can be automatically logged into during testing. 5. Either set the value of `$_full_access_password` in the same script or store it externally using the `priv-set` module with a key path of "accounts.full_access_password". 6. Edit `account: Create Account ( Name ; PrivSet ; Password )` to have two `Add Account` script steps for each of your privilege sets, one within the `$$_FUNIT_TESTING` block that does not expire the password and one within the `Else` block that does. 7. Create a "Guest" privilege set that has View and Edit privileges for your users table, View Only privileges to a layout with context into your users table, and "fmwebdirect", "fmapp", "fmextscriptaccess", and "fmurlscript" extended privileges. 8. The "Guest" privilege set should have "execute only" access to the same scripts it does in this file. 9. Enable the "[Guest]" account and assign it to the "Guest" privilege set. 10. Set the file options to automatically log in as "Guest". 11. You may need to execute this line on the machine running FileMaker Server: fmsadmin set serverconfig securefilesonly=false 12. Call `accounts: Login` from your `OnFirstWindowOpen` script. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- After the above steps have been completed, opening the file will present a custom dialog box to the user that performs similarly to FileMaker's built-in login dialog, but has an additional button, "Forgot PW". If the user enters the correct credentials, they're logged in as normal, but if they click "Forgot PW" their Slack ID is looked up from their account name and link is sent to them. The link is unique to their account and expires after one hour. When they click the link they execute the `accounts: Reset Password ( Token )` script, which will seach for the account record that matches the token and prompt them to enter a new password. The other scripts are simple in comparison, and generally just do what they say. To create a new account, call `accounts: Create ( Auth ; Name ; PrivSet )`, and do likewise for deleting and account or changing an account password. The `Auth` parameter in those three scripts is used to programatically determine if the current user is authorized to change the account password. Passing `True` to this parameter means the current user is authorized. Anything else is interpreted to be an error message that will be presented to the user, so an example of an unauthorized user's paramter might be `script.Param ( "Auth" ; "You do not have authorization to change that user's password." )`. The `accounts: Link Account to Record` is called by `accounts: Login`, but if you're not using login override script, you can use this manually to use the logged in user's account name and look up their primary key, which will then be stored in `$$_LOGGED_IN_USER_ID`. Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-05-14 1.0.1 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-05-15 - Update to take advantage of FileMaker 17's input field to variable feature 1.0.2 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 18-07-30 - Update to take advantage of dialog-loop module 1.0.3 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-07-07 - Remove dependency on `utilities` module Update documentation 1.1.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 19-08-22 - Add ability for a useer to reset a forgotten password [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return a let-notation structure of the settings needed for the module. Return: A standard let-notation dictionary with the following potential keys: ~success: `True` if the script has no errors, `False` otherwise ~error: Optional: The error code if an error occurs ~account_name_field: The fully-qualified name of the field that stores a user's account name ~full_access_account: The account name of the full access account needed during automated testing ~full_access_password: The password of the full access account needed during automated testing Version: 19-08-22 - Charles Ross 19-09-13 - Charles Ross - Add support for `private` module Notes: This module supports the `private` module for storing sensitive information in a separate file. Within the `priv-set` JSON, the full access password should be stored within this module's settings using a "full_access_password" key.
DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE

Calculation.Text: let.Set ( "~success" ; True ) & let.Set ( "~account_name_field" ; $_account_name_field ) & let.Set ( "~slack_id_field" ; $_slack_id_field ) & let.Set ( "~full_access_account" ; $_full_access_account ) & let.Set ( "~full_access_password" ; $_full_access_password )

Comment.value: Purpose: Offer a dialog box allowing the user to reset their password using an expiring token. Parameters: Token: A unique token that includes an expiration after an hour Return: A standard let-notation dictionary with the following potential keys: ~success: `True` if the script has no errors, `False` otherwise ~error: Optional: The error code if an error occurs Version: 19-08-22 - Charles Ross Notes: The token is compared to a hash value stored in the user's record To Do: Why am I using a new window find instead of `sql.SelectFromWhereValue`?

Calculation.Text: Let ( [ _param = Get ( ScriptParameter ) ; _words = list.CreateList ( _param ; "-" ) ; _hex = RightWords ( _words ; 1 ) ; _timestamp = GetAsTimestamp ( math.BaseToInteger ( _hex ; 16 ) ) ; _expired = Get ( CurrentTimestamp ) > _timestamp ; _valid = Get ( CurrentTimestamp ) > _timestamp ; _expired = Get ( CurrentTimestamp ) < ( _timestamp + 3600 ) ; _ = "" ] ; _valid and ( not _expired ) )

accounts priv: Link Account to Record

Comment.value: Purpose: Use the module settings to find the user record that matches the logged in user Return: A standard let-notation dictionary with the following potential keys: ~success: `True` if the script has no errors, `False` otherwise ~error: Optional: The error code if an error occurs Version: 19-08-17 - Charles Ross Notes: Exits the application if the link cannot be made

Calculation.Text: Let ( [ _sql = List ( "SELECT _id_field" ; "FROM _user_table" ; "WHERE _account_field = ?" ) ; _account_field = Quote ( dev.ParseQualifiedField ( $~account_name_field ; "field" ) ) ; _user_table = Quote ( dev.ParseQualifiedField ( $~account_name_field ; "table" ) ) ; _id_field = Quote ( $~pk_name ) ; _sql = Substitute ( _sql ; [ "_account_field" ; _account_field ] ; [ "_user_table" ; _user_table ] ; [ "_id_field" ; _id_field ] ) ; _result = ExecuteSQL ( _sql ; dev.Nil ; dev.Nil ; Get ( AccountName ) ) ; _ = "" ] ; _result )
let.Set ( "~success" ; False ) & let.Set ( "~error" ; "There an error in the SQL" )
"No record was found for account " & Quote ( Get ( AccountName ) ) & ". Please contact the developer."

Comment.value: project 1.0.1 ============= The `project` module provides various tools to work with a FileMaker project, especially an open source one or simply one that will use source control. Requirements ------------ - FileMaker 18+ - This file's custom function library - This file's dialog module - FileMaker Server running locally on macOS - A git repository hosted on GitHub with a local copy Integration Instructions ------------------------ 1. Import all of the custom functions from this file. 2. Import the `project` folder of scripts. 3. Edit the `project: Settings` script to set the following variables: - $_project_directory: The absolute path to the project's repository directory - $_key_file: The name of the file that will contain the encryption key - $_store_key_globally: If set to `True` the encryption key will be stored in a global variable on first read and read from that upon subsequent needs - $_fms_username: The username for using the `fmsadmin` command line tool - $_fms_password: The password for `fmsadmin`, expected to be encrypted with the key found in the key file, call `project: Encrypt ( { String } )` with no parameters to be prompted for a string to encrypt using the encryption key in the key file and receive the encrypted password in a dialog box where you can copy it. See the "Script Parameters" section of the "Conventions" script instructions for passing parameters to public scripts. Usage ----- When you're ready to create a new commit, execute `project: Commit`. This script will perform the following steps: - Prompt the user for a commit comment - Create a new backup of the current file and move the backup to the project folder - Save the file's XML representation - Convert XML f - Add all files in the project folder to the git repository - Commit the files with the given comment The ability to encrypt and decrypt data using an externally stored key first arose with this module, which is why it has that functionality. If you'd like to encrypt a string using the encryption key stored in the key file, call `project: Encrypt ( { String } )`. If you don't pass a parameter, you'll be prompted to provide the string in a dialog box. Similarly, to decrypt a string encrypted with the externally stored encryption key, call `project: Decrypt ( { String } )`. To Do ----- Support the ability to push the repository Support the ability to store hosted files in subfolders Version History --------------- 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 20-01-10 1.0.0 - [Charles Ross][chuck] - 20-01-10 - Use "Save as XML" instead of DDR, remove Read Key script [chuck]: mailto:chivalry@mac.com

Purpose: Return a let-notation structure of the settings needed for the module. Return: A standard `~success` keyed let-notation dictionary with the following additional keys ~project_directory: The directory where the DDR should be stored ~key_file: The name of the file in the project directory that stores the encryption key ~store_key_globally: If `True`, the encryption key will be stored in a global variable the each time it's retrieved (`$$_PROJECT_MODULE_ENCRYPTION_KEY`), defaults to `False` ~fms_username: The username to use when accessing the server with `fmsadmin` ~fms_password: The password to use when accessing the server with `fmsadmin`, expected to have been encrypted using the key in the key file Version: 20-01-10 - Charles Ross
DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE

Calculation.Text: let.Set ( "~success" ; True ) & let.Set ( "~project_directory" ; $_project_directory ) & let.Set ( "~key_file" ; $_key_file ) & let.Set ( "~store_key_globally" ; $_store_key_globally ) & let.Set ( "~fms_username" ; $_fms_username ) & let.Set ( "~fms_password" ; $_fms_password )

Let ( [ _cmd = List ( "cd {{$~project_directory}}" ; "fmsadmin backup {{$_filename}} --username \"{{$~fms_username}}\" --password \"{{$~fms_password}}\" --keep 0" ; "mv \"{{$_backup_folder}}{{$_filename}}\" {{$~project_directory}}" ; "rm -r \"{{$_backup_folder}}\"" ; // "vim {{$_xml_name}} -c \"s/\r/\r/g\" -c \"set fileencoding=utf8\" -c \"wq\"" ; "git add ." ; "git commit -a -m \"{{$_msg}}\"" ) ; $_filename = Get ( FileName ) & ".fmp12" ; $_xml_name = Get ( FileName ) & ".xml" ; $_backup_folder = "/Library/FileMaker Server/Data/Backups/Databases/" ; _cmd = text.SubstituteVariables ( _cmd ) ; _cmd = list.ReplaceSeparator ( _cmd ; " ; " ) ; _ = "" ] ; _cmd )
